Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Utilization of a Combustion Process to Rapidly Solidify a Photocuring Composite Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project will be the research and development of a new class of extremely portable deployable structures that allows easier transportation and simplifies the deployment of bulky structure. This fundamental technology covers a wide variety of potential commercial products including large easily transported rescue equipment and large tents for earthquake and other widespread humanitarian disaster scenarios; large space satellite structures such as antennas and optical arrays; large deployable UAV wings; large volumes for habitation or material storage; piping for water, sewage, oil or gas. This technology can help save lives during disasters, ease the transportation of potable water, sewer and energy with lower construction and deployment costs.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) phase I project will entail the systematic analysis and development of a novel highly compact, rapidly deployable composite tube technology. The challenge is to harness and combine the extremely energy dense properties of chemical combustion with a photocuring high-performance structural composite material to create an easily transported structure that can be rapidly deployed. The project will entail experiments to better understand the polymer material properties and tailor them to the electromagnetic spectrum emitted by the combustion. Customization of an adhesive that will combine the necessary viscosity, structural and curing properties. A multiphysics simulation, validated with laboratory experiments, will be used to predict the technology's limitations. The qualifying components will be utilized in a refined design and evaluated by manufacturers for large scale production. These efforts will culminate in scale prototype construction and testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During our phase 1 research award titled: "Utilization of a Combustion Process to Rapidly Solidify a Photocuring Composite Structure", Helios Applied Science Inc. advanced this novel technology from TRL 3 to TRL 4. 

Our development program included the following: 

  1. Accurately determine spectral emission of combustion reaction.
  2. Investigate thermal transport and structural properties using CFD.
  3. Develop photocuring polymer tailored for combustion curing.
  4. Build and evaluate prototype inflatable deployable beams for litter applications.

 

1. Utilizing an Ocean Optics USB2000 spectrometer we obtained the spectra emitted by the combustion process. The measured wavelength ranged from 200-900 nm. We were limited to open air measurements due to the expense and complexity of outfitting a spectrometer to the glass pressure vessel which we typically use to simulate the above ambient pressure environment within a composite tube during deployment. This data revealed the emissive energy during combustion and highlights the spectral regions in which adhesive photoinitiators would be best matched.

2. Two numerical models were created to estimate the flow velocity and composite tube wall temperatures fields induced by the combustion. The models have been set up to run using ANSYS FLUENT. Both models utilize an Eulerian reference frame representation and account for the relative velocity (0.2 m/s) between the composite tube wall and the combustion area during combustion. The models invoke the Boussinesq approximation for natural convection and resolve the convective transfer equations (continuity, Navier-Stokes and thermal energy with an exothermic reaction term) for a non-participating medium. Radiation heat transfer is captured using a surface-to-surface view factor model that assumes opaque, gray, and diffuse surfaces. At the composite tube-fluid interface, the surface energy balance captured the net rate of conductive heat transfer and radiation exchange. Emissivity is assumed to be unity and may be easily altered once experimentally measured. For both models, the nitrogen flow rate is prescribed at the inlet of the domain to be 0.2 m/s and 300oC.

3. Commercial off the shelf photocuring adhesives are typically only sensitive in the near UV (360-400 nm) and a very small offering of adhesives have some sensitivity in the higher energy portion of the blue wavelengths (405 nm). Therefore, we felt that it would be advantageous to develop an adhesive with photoinitiators that were sensitive to the longer wavelengths produced by our combustion system therefore requiring less combustion material and most importantly produce fewer thermal byproducts.

4. Initially in our phase 1 journey we focused on high-strength and high stiffness composite tubes that would lend themselves to hoist and stretcher applications. These composite tubes required 3 to 4 layers of glass fiber fabric with fiber directions oriented to carry the load paths in more optimal manner based on their use case. Our construction of composite tubes is a manual "wet-layup" process and is conducted over cylindrical mandrels. We chose to upgrade our mandrels because prior to this NSF grant our initial mandrel system was a complex, precision machined all metal assembly with no provision for dimensional adjustment. 

After completing a suitable mandrel design, a full-scale demonstration model of a deployable composite load bearing truss was fabricated. This 9.1 lb truss utilized three 57 mm diameter composite tubes each 4 ft in length in a triangular formation and was designed to fit within a backpack in its stowed configuration and was capable of supporting 433 lbs once rigidized. This truss was a successful demonstration of a multi-element structure that shows possible application of our composite technology in significant load-bearing structures such as cranes, bridges, etc.

Towards the end of our phase 1 we moved our focus to lightweight deployable tubing for aerospace applications. Our final demonstration was of the deployment of a thin-wall composite tube with a compact fully portable inflation and rigidization system. This served to demonstrate the technology for aerospace applications. This composite tube was 57 mm in diameter and 1.25 m in length and weighed 305 g. The tube was combined with a compact inflation and rigidization system of our own design. Upon remote command, the pneumatic deployment was completed in 5 seconds followed by initiation of combustion element. Combustion occurred for 45 seconds followed by a 5 second cool down phase during which nitrogen continued to flow through the tube. After 5 minutes the composite tube was fully rigidized and load bearing. The 305 g tube was not tested to failure but was able to support 61 lbs in bending.


Last Modified: 07/09/2021
Modified by: Alfram Bright

Our development program included the following: Accurately determine spectral emission of combustion reaction. Investigate thermal transport and structural properties using CFD. Develop photocuring polymer tailored for combustion curing. Build and evaluate prototype inflatable deployable beams for litter applications. 1. Utilizing an Ocean Optics USB2000 spectrometer we obtained the spectra emitted by the combustion process. The measured wavelength ranged from 200-900 nm. We were limited to open air measurements due to the expense and complexity of outfitting a spectrometer to the glass pressure vessel which we typically use to simulate the above ambient pressure environment within a composite tube during deployment. After completing a suitable mandrel design, a full-scale demonstration model of a deployable composite load bearing truss was fabricated. The tube was combined with a compact inflation and rigidization system of our own design. Upon remote command, the pneumatic deployment was completed in 5 seconds followed by initiation of combustion element. Combustion occurred for 45 seconds followed by a 5 second cool down phase during which nitrogen continued to flow through the tube. After 5 minutes the composite tube was fully rigidized and load bearing. The 305 g tube was not tested to failure but was able to support 61 lbs in bending.
